remarks: Cognate: 3986 peirasmós (from 3985 /peirázō) – temptation, trial, or test – both senses can apply simultaneously (depending on the context). The positive sense (test) and negative sense (temptation) are functions of the context (not merely the words themselves).
1384 dókimos (an adjective, derived from 1209/dexomai, 'to receive, welcome') – properly, what passes the necessary test (scrutiny); hence acceptable because genuine (validated, verified).
Different ways we have seen this,
=> James 1:2 (to try, in order to discover the disposition of a person, or to improve his virtue.)
=> Heb 3:8 (In the same sense the Israelites are said to have tempted or proved God. )
=> Here (signifies to solicit one to sin, and actually to seduce him into sin)
Tempted (Gk. peirazō) is the verb form of the noun translated “trial” (Gk. peirasmos) in James 1:12

but the context shows that different senses of the word are intended. God brings trials in order to strengthen the Christian’s faith. He never tempts, however, because he never desires his people to sin. Christians should never blame God when they do wrong.

applications: ------ We all stumble and make mistakes. -----

------ Medical Malpractice -----

Hospitals and insurers are vigilant about risk managment and risk mitigation
Fair amount of money involved, contributes to the cost of health care.
Little girl with meningitis

No matter how hard you try, how much you study, learn from others..., it happens.
Little like the game of dodge ball. Keep dodging, seeing those around you being hit, as long as you are in the game, the balls keep coming at you.
------Spiritual Malpractice -----
James is telling us with regard to teachers, it is just a matter of time before the teacher commits spiritual malpractice with their teaching.
We all stumble in many ways.
The teacher may work hard, pray hard, but they are not perfect and will eventually stumble in what they say.
Just like some diseases are so sneeky, so are the wisdom and religions of men.
As long as they are opening their mouth and teaching, they are at risk of spiritual malpractice.
------ Judgement -----
When I stumble at work I damage the flesh, but when I stumble as a teacher the damage I cause is far more grave and permanent, damaging the soul.
The physician knows that stumbling can lead to a medical malpractice judgement.
James is telling the teacher to know stumbling in what we teach will lead to a stricter judgement, something far more serious than a medical malpractice.
